combined_title: Defense Secretary Orders Review of Navy Ship Names Amid Controversy
article:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has directed the U.S. Navy to reconsider the names of several ships, including the USNS Harvey Milk, named after the slain gay rights leader, according to multiple reports. This decision has led to a wave of responses, with some criticizing the move as an attempt to erase diversity and inclusion from the military.

The review, as stated in an internal memo by Navy Secretary John Phelan, is targeted at “reestablishing the warrior culture” in the military, a key priority of the Trump administration. Pentagon Spokesman Sean Parnell emphasized that Hegseth is committed to ensuring that all Department of Defense installations and assets reflect the priorities of the Commander-in-Chief, the nation's history, and the warrior ethos.

The USNS Harvey Milk, a replenishment oiler, was named after Harvey Milk, who served as a sailor during the Korean War and was later forced out of the Navy for being gay. Milk made history as one of the first openly gay elected officials in the U.S., serving on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1977. He, along with San Francisco Mayor George Moscone, was assassinated in 1978. The ship was christened under the Biden administration in 2021 and is currently undergoing maintenance in an Alabama shipyard.

The decision to review the ship's name has been met with criticism. Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who represents San Francisco, described the move as "spiteful" and argued that it does not strengthen national security.

Phelan has reportedly put together a small team to review potential name changes. The new name for the USNS Harvey Milk is expected to be announced by the end of June, coinciding with Pride Month. This move aligns with the Trump administration's broader efforts to purge policies and references related to diversity, equity, and inclusion. The Pentagon has not yet revealed the new name for the ship.

WASHINGTON (AP) —Defense Secretary Pete Hegsethhas ordered the Navy to rename the USNS Harvey Milk, a highly rare move that will strip the ship of the moniker of a slain gay rights activist who served as a sailor during the Korean War.
U.S. officials say Navy Secretary John Phelan put together a small team to rename the replenishment oiler and that a new name is expected this month. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal deliberations, said the next name had not yet been chosen.
The change was laid out in an internal memo that officials said defended the action as a move to align with President Donald Trump and Hegseth’s objectives to “re-establish the warrior culture.”
It marks the latest move by Hegseth and the wider Trump administration topurge all programs, policies, books and social media mentionsof references to diversity, equity and inclusion. And it comes duringPride Month— the same timing as the Pentagon’s campaign toforce transgender troops outof the U.S. military.
Pentagon spokesman Sean Parnell said in a statement that Hegseth is “committed to ensuring that the names attached to all DOD installations and assets are reflective of the Commander-in-Chief’s priorities, our nation’s history, and the warrior ethos.”
Phelan’s office did not respond to a request for comment on the decision, which was first reported by Military.com.
